Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Situation2: A rarely used machine shows an intermittent glitch during a slow production period.
Story:
I was in the middle of my shift, hunched over the old packaging machine that had started acting up again. The plant was quiet, the lull in production making every clank and whir echo louder. My supervisor expected me to find the source of the glitch, even though it only happened once in a while and never when anyone else was watching. I could feel the pressure mounting—if I didn’t fix it soon, it would look like I wasn’t doing my job.

My phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a message from Mom: “Can you call when you have a minute?” Lately, I’d been trying to check in more, knowing Dad’s health wasn’t great and Mom got anxious when things felt uncertain. I knew she wanted to talk, maybe just to hear my voice and know I cared. But I was already behind, and the machine’s next hiccup could be my only clue. I stared at my phone, torn between the quiet plea from home and the silent demand of the machine in front of me, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in from either side.
